en: ‚ÄúMy dear fellow, I am not quite serious. But I can‚Äôt help detesting my relations. I suppose it comes from the fact that none of us can stand other people having the same faults as ourselves. I quite sympathize with the rage of the English democracy against what they call the vices of the upper orders. The masses feel that drunkenness, stupidity, and immorality should be their own special property, and that if any one of us makes an ass of himself, he is poaching on their preserves. When poor Southwark got into the divorce court, their indignation was quite magnificent. And yet I don‚Äôt suppose that ten per cent of the proletariat live correctly.‚Äù

en: He began to wonder whether we could ever make psychology so absolute a science that each little spring of life would be revealed to us. As it was, we always misunderstood ourselves and rarely understood others. Experience was of no ethical value. It was merely the name men gave to their mistakes. Moralists had, as a rule, regarded it as a mode of warning, had claimed for it a certain ethical efficacy in the formation of character, had praised it as something that taught us what to follow and showed us what to avoid. But there was no motive power in experience. It was as little of an active cause as conscience itself. All that it really demonstrated was that our future would be the same as our past, and that the sin we had done once, and with loathing, we would do many times, and with joy.

tn: O ne a simolola go ipotsa gore a tota go ka nna ga nna le thuto ya saense e e bontshang gore botshelo bongwe le bongwe jo bo tla re senolelang jone. Le fa go ntse jalo, ka dinako dingwe re ne re sa tlhaloganye sentle e bile ga se gantsi re tlhaloganyang ba bangwe. Go ne go se na mosola ope wa maitsholo. E ne e le leina la gagwe fela le le neng le dira diphoso. Ba ba neng ba na le yone, e le molao, ba ne ba e tsaya e le mokgwa wa tlhagiso, ba ne ba re o na le bokgoni jo bo rileng mo go tlhamiweng ga popego, ba ne ba e galaletsa e le sengwe se se re rutileng se re tshwanetseng go se latela le go re bontsha gore re tshwanetse go tila eng. Le fa go ntse jalo, go ne go sena maatla a go nna le tlhotlheletso mo maitemogelong. E ne e le lebaka le lennye fela la go nna le segakolodi se se sa tshwaneng. Tsotlhe tse go bontshitsweng tota e ne e le gore bokamoso jwa rona bo tla tshwana le jwa rona jwa maloba, le gore boleo jo re neng re bo dirile gangwe fela, le ka go ikgogomotsa, re tla dira ka makgetlo a le mantsi, mme ka boitumelo.

en: Then he leaped up and went to the door. ‚ÄúYes,‚Äù he cried, ‚Äúyou have killed my love. You used to stir my imagination. Now you don‚Äôt even stir my curiosity. You simply produce no effect. I loved you because you were marvellous, because you had genius and intellect, because you realized the dreams of great poets and gave shape and substance to the shadows of art. You have thrown it all away. You are shallow and stupid. My God! how mad I was to love you! What a fool I have been! You are nothing to me now. I will never see you again. I will never think of you. I will never mention your name. You don‚Äôt know what you were to me, once. Why, once ... Oh, I can‚Äôt bear to think of it! I wish I had never laid eyes upon you! You have spoiled the romance of my life. How little you can know of love, if you say it mars your art! Without your art, you are nothing. I would have made you famous, splendid, magnificent. The world would have worshipped you, and you would have borne my name. What are you now? A third-rate actress with a pretty face.‚Äù

U mpa u sa hlahise phello. Ke ne ke u rata hobane u ne u maketse, hobane u ne u na le bohlale le botelletsoeng pele, hobane u hlokometse litoro tsa liroki tse kholo 'me ua fana ka sebopeho le ntho moriting oa bonono. U li lahlile kaofela. U sethoto ebile u sethoto. Modimo wa ka! Ke ne ke hlanya hakaakang ho u rata! Ho ho ho how silly of me! U se ke ua ba letho ho 'na hona joale. Ha ke sa tla hlola ke u bona. 'Me nke ke ka nahana ka uena. Ha ke sa tla hlola ke bolela lebitso la hau. Ha u tsebe seo u neng u tla ho 'na ka nako e le' ngoe. Hang Seng ... Oh, ke sitoa ho mamella ho nahana ka eona! en: He threw himself into a chair and began to think. Suddenly there flashed across his mind what he had said in Basil Hallward‚Äôs studio the day the picture had been finished. Yes, he remembered it perfectly. He had uttered a mad wish that he himself might remain young, and the portrait grow old; that his own beauty might be untarnished, and the face on the canvas bear the burden of his passions and his sins; that the painted image might be seared with the lines of suffering and thought, and that he might keep all the delicate bloom and loveliness of his then just conscious boyhood. Surely his wish had not been fulfilled? Such things were impossible. It seemed monstrous even to think of them. And, yet, there was the picture before him, with the touch of cruelty in the mouth.

Tampoka teo dia nisy zavatra nipoaka tao an-tsainy ny zavatra nolazainy tao amin'ny studio Basil Hallward tamin'ny andro nahavitan'ilay sary. Eny, tsaroany tsara ilay izy. Naniry mafy ny hijanona ho tanora izy, ary mihaantitra ny sary; mba tsy ho voaloto ny hatsaran-tarehiny, ary ny tarehy eo amin' ny lamba hitondra ny enta-mavesatry ny filany sy ny fahotany; fa ny sary hosodoko dia mety ho rakotry ny fijaliana sy ny eritreritra, ary mba hahafahany mitazona ny felam-boninkazo marefo sy ny hatsaran-tarehin'ny fahazazany tamin'izany fotoana izany. Azo antoka fa tsy tanteraka ny faniriany? Tsy azo notanterahina ny zavatra toy izany. Toa tsy misy dikany ny mieritreritra azy ireo. Ary na izany aza, nisy ny sary teo anoloany, miaraka amin'ny fikasihana habibiana tao am-bavany.

en: For there would be a real pleasure in watching it. He would be able to follow his mind into its secret places. This portrait would be to him the most magical of mirrors. As it had revealed to him his own body, so it would reveal to him his own soul. And when winter came upon it, he would still be standing where spring trembles on the verge of summer. When the blood crept from its face, and left behind a pallid mask of chalk with leaden eyes, he would keep the glamour of boyhood. Not one blossom of his loveliness would ever fade. Not one pulse of his life would ever weaken. Like the gods of the Greeks, he would be strong, and fleet, and joyous. What did it matter what happened to the coloured image on the canvas? He would be safe. That was everything.

en: It was a novel without a plot and with only one character, being, indeed, simply a psychological study of a certain young Parisian who spent his life trying to realize in the nineteenth century all the passions and modes of thought that belonged to every century except his own, and to sum up, as it were, in himself the various moods through which the world-spirit had ever passed, loving for their mere artificiality those renunciations that men have unwisely called virtue, as much as those natural rebellions that wise men still call sin. The style in which it was written was that curious jewelled style, vivid and obscure at once, full of argot and of archaisms, of technical expressions and of elaborate paraphrases, that characterizes the work of some of the finest artists of the French school of Symbolistes. There were in it metaphors as monstrous as orchids and as subtle in colour. The life of the senses was described in the terms of mystical philosophy. One hardly knew at times whether one was reading the spiritual ecstasies of some medi√¶val saint or the morbid confessions of a modern sinner. It was a poisonous book. The heavy odour of incense seemed to cling about its pages and to trouble the brain. The mere cadence of the sentences, the subtle monotony of their music, so full as it was of complex refrains and movements elaborately repeated, produced in the mind of the lad, as he passed from chapter to chapter, a form of reverie, a malady of dreaming, that made him unconscious of the falling day and creeping shadows.

tr_results: "Title": "The Picture of Dorian Gray", "Author": "Oscar Wilde"
es: Era una novela sin argumento y con un solo personaje, ya que se trataba, en realidad, de un estudio psicol√≥gico de cierto joven parisino que emple√≥ la vida tratando de experimentar en el siglo XIX todas las pasiones y maneras de pensar pertenecientes a los siglos anteriores al suyo, resumiendo en s√≠ mismo, por as√≠ decirlo, los diferentes estados de √°nimo por los que hab√≠a pasado el esp√≠ritu del mundo, y que am√≥, por su misma artificialidad, esos renunciamientos a los que los hombres llaman err√≥neamente virtudes, al igual que las rebeld√≠as naturales a las que los prudentes llaman pecados. El libro estaba escrito en un estilo curiosamente ornamental, gr√°fico y oscuro al mismo tiempo, lleno de argot y de arca√≠smos, de expresiones t√©cnicas y de las complicadas per√≠frasis que caracterizan la obra de algunos de los mejores artistas de la escuela simbolista francesa. Hab√≠a en √©l met√°foras tan monstruosas como orqu√≠deas, y con la misma sutileza de color. Se describ√≠a la vida de los sentidos con el lenguaje de la filosof√≠a m√≠stica. A veces era dif√≠cil saber si se estaba leyendo la descripci√≥n de los √©xtasis de alg√∫n santo medieval o las morbosas confesiones de un pecador moderno. Era un libro venenoso. El denso olor del incienso parec√≠a desprenderse de sus p√°ginas y turbar el cerebro. La cadencia misma de las frases, la sutil monoton√≠a de su m√∫sica, tan lleno como estaba de complejos estribillos y de movimientos elaboradamente repetidos, produjo en la mente de Dorian Gray, al pasar de cap√≠tulo en cap√≠tulo, algo semejante a una enso√±aci√≥n, una enfermedad del sue√±o que le hizo no darse cuenta de que iba cayendo el d√≠a y creciendo las sombras.
es_results: "Title": "The Picture of Dorian Gray", "Author": "Oscar Wilde"
st: E ne e le buka e ntle morero le ka semelo se le seng feela, ho ba, ka sebele, feela e le thuto ea kelello ea e monyenyane Parisian ea ileng a qeta bophelo ba hae ba leka ho hlokomela lekholong la leshome le metso e robong la lilemo litabatabelo tsohle le mekhoa ea ho nahana hore e ne e le ea mong le e mong lekholo ntle le ea hae, le ho sum ho fihlela, joalokaha ho ne ho le joalo,  Ka boeena ke maikutlo a fapaneng ao moea oa lefats'e o kileng oa feta ka oona, a ratang feela maiketsetso a bona ao banna ba sa kang ba a bitsa bokhabane, joalo ka bofetoheli boo batho ba bohlale ba ntseng ba bitsa sebe. Setaele seo ho sona ho neng ho ngoloa e ne e le hore bohelehele ba setaele, se hlakileng ebile se sa hlaka ka nako e le ngoe, se tletse argot le li-archaisms, tsa lipolelo tsa tekheniki le tsa li-pararasephs tse majabajaba, tse khethollang mosebetsi oa bataki ba bang ba hloahloa ba sekolo sa Fora sa Symbolistes. Ho ne ho e-na le papiso ea eona e le monstrous joalo ka li-orchid le tse poteletseng ka 'mala. Bophelo ba li-senses bo hlalositsoe ho latela filosofi ea mystical. Ka linako tse ling o ne a sa tsebe hore na motho o ne a bala ecstasies ea ba bang ba mohalaleli ea halalelang kapa boipolelo ba morbid ea moetsalibe oa kajeno. E ne e le buka ea chefo. Monko o boima oa libano o ne o bonahala o khomarela maqephe a eona le ho khathatsa boko. The cadence feela ea lipoleloana, le monotony poteletseng tsa 'mino oa bona, tletse joalo ka ha e ne e le ea refrains rarahaneng le metsamao ka elaborately pheta-pheta, hlahisoang kelellong ea lad, ha a ntse a feta ho tloha khaolong ho khaolo ho ea khaolong, mofuta reverie, e malady ea toro, e ileng ea etsa hore a sa tsebe letho ka letsatsi oela le meriti e hahabang.

tn: E ne e le buka e e senang morero mme e na le semelo se le sengwe fela, ka gonne, e le thuto fela ya semoya ya kwa Paris yo o rileng yo o neng a tshela botshelo jwa gagwe a leka go lemoga mo lekgolong la bo19 la dingwaga, dikeletso le mekgwa yotlhe ya go akanya e e neng e le ya ngwagakgolo mongwe le mongwe, ntle le ya gagwe, le go akaretsa, jaaka go ne go le jalo,  15 Ka bopelotshetlha tse di farologaneng tse mowa wa lefatshe o kileng wa di feta ka tsone, di rata go nna fela boiposo tse batho ba di bitsang bopelotshetlha, fela jaaka ditsuolodi tseo tsa tlhago tse banna ba ba botlhale ba sa ntseng ba di bitsa boleo. Setaele se go neng go kwadilwe ka sone e ne e le gore setaele se se monate, se se bonalang sentle le se se sa lefifi ka nako e le nngwe, se tletse di-argot le tsa di-archaism, tsa mafoko a botegeniki le tsa diparara tse di bonalang sentle, tse di supang tiro ya bangwe ba bataki ba ba molemo ba sekolo sa Fora sa Matshwao. Go ne go na le ditshwantshiso tse di jaaka monstrous jaaka di-orchid le tse di bidiwang mmala. Go ne ga tlhalosiwa gore botshelo jwa motho bo ne jwa tlhalosiwa mo filosofing ya se-mystical. Ka dinako tse dingwe o ne a itse gore a o ne a bala dilo tsa semoya tse di mo baebeleng kgotsa tse di sa tswang go nna le bodumedi jo bo sa raraanang. E ne e le buka e e botlhole. Go ne go lebega go na le monko o o bokete o o fisang mo ditsebeng tsa yone le go fudusa boboko. Go na le dikakany√¥ tse di kwa tlase tsa mmino wa bone, tse di tletseng ka fa e ne e le tsa dikakany√¥ tse di raraaneng le metsamao e e raraaneng, e e tlhagisitseng mo tlhaloganyong ya lad, fa a feta go tswa kgaolong go ya go kgaolo, mofuta wa boiphepa, e leng mmalo wa toro, e e neng ya dira gore a se ka a gopola letsatsi le meriti e e gagabang.

mg: Tantara tsy misy teti-dratsy izany ary tsy misy afa-tsy olona iray ihany, tena, fandalinana ara-tsaina fotsiny momba ny tanora Pariziana iray izay nandany ny fiainany tamin'ny fiezahana hahatsapa ny firehetam-po sy ny fomba fisainana rehetra izay an'ny taonjato tsirairay afa-tsy ny azy, ary ny hamintina, toy ny hoe,  Ao amin'ny tenany ireo toe-tsaina isan-karazany izay efa nandalovan'ny fanahin'izao tontolo izao, fitiavana ny fahatsoran'izy ireo fotsiny ireo fialana izay nantsoin'ny olona hoe hatsaran-toetra, tahaka ireo fikomiana voajanahary izay mbola antsoin'ny olon-kendry hoe fahotana. Ny fomba nanoratana azy dia ny fomba fanao mahavariana amin'ny firavaka, mazava sy tsy mazava amin'ny fotoana iray, feno argot sy archaisms, fanehoan-kevitra ara-teknika sy paraphrases, izay mampiavaka ny asan'ny sasany amin'ireo mpanakanto tsara indrindra ao amin'ny sekoly frantsay Symbolistes. Nisy fanoharana toy ny orkide sy ny loko an - kolaka. Ny fiainan'ny saina dia nofaritana tamin'ny resaka filozofia mistika. Indraindray dia zara raha misy olona iray mamaky ny fifaliana ara-panahin'ny olomasina medi√¶val sasany na ny fiaiken-keloka mahatsiravina nataon'ny mpanota maoderina. Boky misy poizina izany. Toa nifikitra tamin'ny pejiny sy nanakorontana ny atidoha ilay fofona mavesatra avy amin'ny emboka manitra. Ny fehezan-teny tsotra fotsiny, ny tsy fahampian'ny mozikan'izy ireo, feno toy ny feon-kira sarotra sy ny fihetsiketsehana miverimberina, novokarina tao an-tsain'ilay zazalahy, rehefa niampita ny toko ho toko izy, endrika fanajana, nofy ratsy, izay nahatonga azy tsy nahatsiaro ny andro nianjera sy ny aloka mikisaka.

en: And, certainly, to him life itself was the first, the greatest, of the arts, and for it all the other arts seemed to be but a preparation. Fashion, by which what is really fantastic becomes for a moment universal, and dandyism, which, in its own way, is an attempt to assert the absolute modernity of beauty, had, of course, their fascination for him. His mode of dressing, and the particular styles that from time to time he affected, had their marked influence on the young exquisites of the Mayfair balls and Pall Mall club windows, who copied him in everything that he did, and tried to reproduce the accidental charm of his graceful, though to him only half-serious, fopperies.

en: But he never fell into the error of arresting his intellectual development by any formal acceptance of creed or system, or of mistaking, for a house in which to live, an inn that is but suitable for the sojourn of a night, or for a few hours of a night in which there are no stars and the moon is in travail. Mysticism, with its marvellous power of making common things strange to us, and the subtle antinomianism that always seems to accompany it, moved him for a season; and for a season he inclined to the materialistic doctrines of the Darwinismus movement in Germany, and found a curious pleasure in tracing the thoughts and passions of men to some pearly cell in the brain, or some white nerve in the body, delighting in the conception of the absolute dependence of the spirit on certain physical conditions, morbid or healthy, normal or diseased. Yet, as has been said of him before, no theory of life seemed to him to be of any importance compared with life itself. He felt keenly conscious of how barren all intellectual speculation is when separated from action and experiment. He knew that the senses, no less than the soul, have their spiritual mysteries to reveal.

Mysticism, ka matla a eona a hlollang a ho etsa lintho tse tloaelehileng tse sa tloaelehang ho rona, le antinomianism e poteletseng eo kamehla ho bonahalang eka e tsamaea le eona, e mo susumelletse nako ea selemo; 'Me ka nako e itseng o ile a t≈°ekamelo lithutong tse bonahalang tsa mokhatlo oa Darwinismus Jeremane, 'me o ile a fumana thabo e makatsang ea ho tracing mehopolo le litakatso tsa banna ho ba bang ba perela seleng ea perela bokong, kapa ba bang ba t≈°oeu methapo ea' mele, thabela ho emoloa ka ho feletseng ho it≈°etleha ha moea ka maemo a itseng a 'mele,  Morbid kapa e phetseng hantle, e tloaelehileng kapa e kula. Leha ho le joalo, joalo ka ha ho boletsoe ka eena pejana, ha ho na khopolo ea bophelo e neng e bonahala e le ea bohlokoa ho eena ha e bapisoa le bophelo ka boeona. O ile a ikutloa a tseba ka matla hore na likhopolo-taba tsohle tsa kelello li joang ha li arohana le ketso le teko. O ne a tseba hore kutlo, eseng ka tlase ho moya, di nale diphiri tsa bona tsa semoya hoka senolwa.

tn: Le fa go ntse jalo, ga a ise a ke a tsene mo phosong ya go tshwara tlhabololo ya tlhaloganyo ya gagwe ka kamogelo ya semmuso ya tumelo kgotsa tsamaiso, kgotsa ya bosula, mo ntlong e mo go yone go nnang mo go yone, e e siametseng go ja bosigo, kgotsa diura di le mmalwa mo bosigong jo go se nang dinaledi le ngwedi mo travail. 18 Ka go rata ga gagwe, ka nonofo ya gagwe e e gakgamatsang ya go dira dilo tse di tlwaelegileng tse di sa tlwaelegang, le boganetsi jo bo sa tlwaelegang jo bo bonalang bo ntse bo tsamaya le jone, bo mo fudugetse ka lobaka lwa ngwaga. Mme ka nako e nngwe o ne a seka a leba dithuto tsa bomoya tsa motsamao wa Darwin mo Jeremane, mme a bona boitumelo jo bo gakgamatsang mo go laoleng dikakanyo le dikeletso tsa batho mo seleng nngwe ya perela mo bokong, kgotsa go nna le pelo e tshweu mo mmeleng, e e itumedisang ka go ikaega ga moya ka botlalo mo maemong a a rileng a mmele,  go nna mo mmeleng o o siameng, o o tlwaelegileng kgotsa o lwala. Le fa go ntse jalo, jaaka a setse a kile a bua ka ene, go ne go se na ope yo o neng a tshela botshelo jo bo tshwanang le jwa gagwe. O ne a ikutlwa a tshwenyegile thata ka gore ke eng se se dirang gore batho botlhe ba se ka ba dira dilo tse ba di dirang le gore ba se ka ba dira dilo tse ba di dirang. O ne a itse gore tlhaloganyo, e seng kwa tlase ga moya, e na le masaitsiweng a bone a semowa.

en: For these treasures, and everything that he collected in his lovely house, were to be to him means of forgetfulness, modes by which he could escape, for a season, from the fear that seemed to him at times to be almost too great to be borne. Upon the walls of the lonely locked room where he had spent so much of his boyhood, he had hung with his own hands the terrible portrait whose changing features showed him the real degradation of his life, and in front of it had draped the purple-and-gold pall as a curtain. For weeks he would not go there, would forget the hideous painted thing, and get back his light heart, his wonderful joyousness, his passionate absorption in mere existence. Then, suddenly, some night he would creep out of the house, go down to dreadful places near Blue Gate Fields, and stay there, day after day, until he was driven away. On his return he would sit in front of the picture, sometimes loathing it and himself, but filled, at other times, with that pride of individualism that is half the fascination of sin, and smiling with secret pleasure at the misshapen shadow that had to bear the burden that should have been his own.

es: Porque aquellos tesoros y todo lo que coleccionaba en su hermosa mansi√≥n estaba destinado a servirle de medio para el olvido, eran una manera de escapar, durante una temporada, al miedo que a veces le parec√≠a casi demasiado intenso para poder soportarlo. En una pared de la solitaria habitaci√≥n, siempre cerrada con llave, donde transcurriera una parte tan considerable de su infancia y adolescencia, hab√≠a colgado con sus propias manos el terrible retrato cuyos rasgos cambiantes le mostraban la verdadera degradaci√≥n de su vida, y delante, a modo de cortina, hab√≠a colocado el pa√±o mortuorio de color morado y oro. Pasaba semanas sin subir, olvid√°ndose de aquella espantosa pintura, recuperando la ligereza de esp√≠ritu, la maravillosa alegr√≠a de vivir, dej√°ndose absorber apasionadamente por la existencia misma. Luego, de repente, una noche cualquiera, sal√≠a furtivamente de su casa, bajaba hasta alguno de los terribles lugares pr√≥ximos a Blue Gate Fields, y all√≠ se quedaba, por espacio de varios d√≠as, hasta que lo echaban. tn: Gonne matlotlo ano, le sengwe le sengwe se a neng a se kokoanya mo ntlong ya gagwe e e rategang, mo go ene di ne di tshwanetse go nna tsela ya go lebala, mekgwa e a neng a ka tshaba ka yone, ka lobaka lo lo rileng, mo poifong e ka dinako tse dingwe e neng e lebega e batla e le kgolo thata go ka nna . rwalwa. Mo maboteng a phaposi e e notletsweng e e jewang ke bodutu e a neng a e feditse bontsi jwa bosimane jwa gagwe mo go yone, o ne a lepeletse ka diatla tsa gagwe setshwantsho se se boitshegang se dipopego tsa sone tse di fetogang di neng di mmontsha go senyega ga mmatota ga botshelo jwa gagwe, mme fa pele ga sone go ne go apesitswe mmala wa phepole- le-pall ya gauta jaaka gareteni. Ka dibeke di le dintsi o ne a sa ye koo, a lebala selo se se maswe se se takilweng, mme a boelwa ke pelo ya gagwe e e botlhofo, boitumelo jwa gagwe jo bo gakgamatsang, go tsenelela ga gagwe ka lorato mo go nneng teng fela. Mme, ka tshoganyetso, bosigo bongwe o ne a tla gagaba go tswa mo ntlong, a fologela kwa mafelong a a boitshegang gaufi le Blue Gate Fields, mme a nne koo, letsatsi le letsatsi, go fitlhela a lelekwa. Fa a boa o ne a tla nna fa pele ga setshwantsho, ka dinako tse dingwe a se ila le ene ka boene, mme a tletse, ka dinako tse dingwe, ka boikgogomoso joo jwa go nna motho ka bongwe jo e leng halofo ya go kgatlhwa ke boleo, mme a nyenya ka boitumelo jwa sephiri mo moriting o o sa bopegang sentle o o neng o tshwanetse go . rwala morwalo o o neng o tshwanetse go nna wa gagwe.

en: For, while he fascinated many, there were not a few who distrusted him. He was very nearly blackballed at a West End club of which his birth and social position fully entitled him to become a member, and it was said that on one occasion, when he was brought by a friend into the smoking-room of the Churchill, the Duke of Berwick and another gentleman got up in a marked manner and went out. Curious stories became current about him after he had passed his twenty-fifth year. It was rumoured that he had been seen brawling with foreign sailors in a low den in the distant parts of Whitechapel, and that he consorted with thieves and coiners and knew the mysteries of their trade. His extraordinary absences became notorious, and, when he used to reappear again in society, men would whisper to each other in corners, or pass him with a sneer, or look at him with cold searching eyes, as though they were determined to discover his secret.

en: How exquisite they were! As one read them, one seemed to be floating down the green water-ways of the pink and pearl city, seated in a black gondola with silver prow and trailing curtains. The sudden flashes of colour reminded him of the gleam of the opal-and-iris-throated birds that flutter round the tall honeycombed Campanile, or stalk, with such stately grace, through the dim, dust-stained arcades. en: Suddenly he started. His eyes grew strangely bright, and he gnawed nervously at his underlip. Between two of the windows stood a large Florentine cabinet, made out of ebony and inlaid with ivory and blue lapis. He watched it as though it were a thing that could fascinate and make afraid, as though it held something that he longed for and yet almost loathed. His breath quickened. A mad craving came over him. He lit a cigarette and then threw it away. His eyelids drooped till the long fringed lashes almost touched his cheek. But he still watched the cabinet. At last he got up from the sofa on which he had been lying, went over to it, and having unlocked it, touched some hidden spring. A triangular drawer passed slowly out. His fingers moved instinctively towards it, dipped in, and closed on something. It was a small Chinese box of black and gold-dust lacquer, elaborately wrought, the sides patterned with curved waves, and the silken cords hung with round crystals and tasselled in plaited metal threads. He opened it. Inside was a green paste, waxy in lustre, the odour curiously heavy and persistent.

mg: Tampoka teo dia nanomboka izy. Namirapiratra hafahafa ny masony, ary nivazavaza tamim - pitaintainana teo amin'ny molony izy. Teo anelanelan'ny varavarankely roa dia nisy kabinetra lehibe iray tao Florentine, vita avy amin'ny ebony ary nasiana vangin'elefanta sy lapis manga. Nijery izany izy toy ny hoe zavatra mety hahavariana sy hampatahotra izany, toy ny hoe misy zavatra izay niriany nefa saika halainy. Nalaky ny fofon'ainy. Nisy faniriana adala tonga teo aminy. Nifoka sigara iray izy ary avy eo nanipy izany. Nipitika ny hodimasony mandra - pahatongan'ireo kapoka lava be teo amin'ny takolany. Na izany aza, mbola nijery ny kabinetra ihany izy. Tamin'ny farany dia nitsangana avy teo amin'ny sezalava izay nandaingany izy, nanatona azy, ary rehefa avy nanokatra izany izy dia nikasika loharano miafina. Nisy vatasarihana telo nivoaka tsikelikely. Ny rantsan-tanany dia niroso ho azy nankany amin'izany, niroboka ary nanakatona zavatra iray. Boaty Shinoa kely misy lacquer mainty sy volamena izy io, izay voatetika tsara, ny sisiny dia misy onja miforona, ary ny tady silke mihantona amin'ny kristaly boribory sy voatetika amin'ny kofehy vy mifono tsimparifary. Nosokafany ilay izy. Tao anatiny dia nisy paty maitso, savoka tao anatin'ny filan-dratsy, ary ny fofona dia tena mavesatra sy maharitra.

It was not till they had examined the rings that they recognized who it was.
